title: What is the main cause of death?
What are the cause-specific mortality rates?
Which age group is most affected?
options: All age groups are equally affected

title: Is there any specific problem regarding the mortality rates?
Is there a designated burial area? If so, How are they happening?
Is there any specific problem regarding nutrition?
Do you have staff trained/specialized on nutrition?
Where do you refer to severe cases of malnutrition?
Is there any education given to mothers on healthy nutrition?
Are there any populations/groups with higher rates of malnutrition than others?
How many cases of acute malnutrition are known at the moment?
How many cases of acute malnutrition are referred to the patient feeding programme?
Are the schools operating?
Is there any alternative education available?
Are the schools physically accessible?
What do local authorities do about the education status?
options: Collaborate with NGOs for education support

title: Who are the actors working in education in the area?
Is there any existing support accessible for the community?
What specific services is the organization providing and in what setting?
options: Vocational training in specialized training centers
Online courses and digital learning platforms
Adult education programs in local facilities
Early childhood education in preschools or kindergartens

Literacy programs for disadvantaged groups
h

title: What existing support is accessible for the community?
Who provides non-formal educational activities?
Are learning materials available?
Does non-formal education exist?
Is online learning offered?
How is the quality of the online education?
How is the quality of in person education?
What condition are the schools in?
Are the schools being used as shelters?
Are students attending school?
Is participation at school dependent on Age?
Is participation at school dependent on Gender?
What are the reasons why children don’t attend schools/learning centers?
Are there high risk populations among the students?
Are there language barriers?
Is there a need for translation?
How can we identify partners for dealing with language barriers?
Are there refugees that were teachers before?
How can they be supported and integrated? Are there specific training requirements?
options: Financial support for resources and infrastructure
Integration into existing programs and initiatives
Collaboration with relevant stakeholders and organizations
Training in specific skills and knowledge
Customized training based on identified needs

title: What possible collaborations exist for dealing education for Refugees/IDPs/Migrants?
options: Collaboration with local schools and universities
Joint efforts with host country's education authorities
Engagement of private sector for funding and resources
Limited collaborative efforts for education provision

title: Are any extracurricular activities offered? (refer to MHPSS)
Are there any vulnerable populations in your community?
State the vulnerable populations in your community
Are you aware of any risks to vulnerable populations in your community? (e.g. CP risks, GBV)
Do vulnerable populations have access to shelters or safe spaces?
Since the emergency what changes have you noticed in yourself?
What do community members normally do to overcome difficulties/deal with distress?
options: Mutual support and solidarity. Seeking help from local leaders
Engaging in religious or spiritual practices

title: What are the existing support services in your community?
What are the existing referral pathways (local and national)
options: Referral to local health clinics or hospitals
Direct communication with local community leaders
Referral to specialized mental health services

title: Are there specific locations within the community that are unsafe?
What organizations are currently involved within the community?
What gaps are there within the community in terms of access to information and services (including referral pathways)
options: Lack of access to clean water and sanitation information
Limited access to emergency response information
No specific gaps in access identified

title: If it’s a host community - what is the relationship between the host community and the IDP community
options: Varies depending on the specific context

title: What water, sanitation and hygiene practices were the population accustomed to before the crisis?
options: Lack of knowledge about referral options
Absence of translated materials for diverse groups

title: Are there any existing practices harmful to health?
What existing practices are harmful to health?
options: Limited hand hygiene. Overconsumption of sugary foods. Lack of vaccination awareness

title: Who practices these and why?
Is there an understanding of the relationship between water/sanitation/shelter and disease?
What are the common hygiene practices among the affected population. ?
Is there a need for any type of hygiene items or other NFIs?
Does the community have access to facilities important for maintaining hygiene?
hintText: covered water containers /cooking utensils/ mosquito nets/soap/sanitary protection

title: What would motivate the community to practice positive hygiene behavior?
options: Access to clean water and sanitation facilities
Health education and awareness campaigns. Incentives or rewards for practicing hygiene
Availability of hygiene supplies and products
Reduction in illness and disease transmission
Cultural and religious beliefs promoting hygiene

title: Are there any hygiene promotion activities linked with water and sanitation and/or health services?
What are the learning needs of hygiene promotion staff and community outreach workers?
options: Training in using hygiene promotion materials

title: What type of outreach system would work in this context for both immediate and medium-term mobilization?
What are the advantages and disadvantages of any proposed changes in practice?
What non-food items are available?
What are the most urgently needed based on preferences and needs?
Has the place where people access markets to buy their essential hygiene items (cost, diversity, quality) changed since the crisis? Where is it now?
How do households access their essential hygiene items?
options: No clear method for accessing items

title: Who makes the decisions regarding which items to buy and prioritize?
How effective are hygiene practices in healthcare settings (particularly important in epidemic situations)?
What are the needs and preferences of women and girls for menstrual hygiene practices?
options: Access to sanitary pads or menstrual products
Availability of clean and private sanitation facilities
Disposal options for used menstrual materials
Access to pain relief and hygiene education
No specific needs or preferences identified

title: What are the needs and preferences of people living with incontinence?
options: Availability of clean and accessible restroom facilities
Disposal options for used incontinence products
Access to medical advice and assistance
Privacy and dignity in managing incontinence
No specific needs or preferences identified

title: Is the water clean and portable?
What treatment is necessary?
Are there alternative water sources nearby?
Is it possible to tanker water if water sources are inadequate?
What are the key hygiene issues related to water supply?
options: Difficulty in water access for hygiene

title: Is water accessible to all community members?
How was the drinking water affected by the situation? ?
options: No significant impact on drinking water

title: What is the main water source?
options: No specific main water source identified

title: Was the drinking water affected by the situation?
Do people have the means to use water hygienically in this situation?
How much water is available per person per day?
What is the daily and weekly frequency of the water supply availability?
Is the water available at the source enough for short term and longer term needs?
Do people have enough water containers of the right size and type?
do all groups (e.g. men, women, caste’s, etc.) have equitable access to water?
Are water collection points close enough (less than 500m away) to where people live?
Are the collection points safe and secure?
Does the community have problems with water palatability and acceptance associated with chlorine taste and smell?
What traditional beliefs and practices relate to the collection, storage and use of water?
options: Offering water to ancestors or deities
No distinct traditional beliefs or practices

title: Has this access (the cost, quality, regularity of delivery) changed?
Are waterpoints and laundry and bathing areas well drained?
Are soil conditions suitable for on-site or off-site management of problem water from water points and laundry and bathing areas?
Has a soil percolation test been carried out?
What is the usual source of water for livestock?
options: No specific water source for livestock

title: Will there be any environmental effects due to possible water supply intervention, abstraction and use of water sources?
Is there a risk of conflict if the sources are utilised for new populations? If so, what other users are currently using the water sources for?
Are the users involved in the management and maintenance of water sources and latrines? If not, are there other people/organizations?
What opportunities are there to collaborate with the private and/or public sector in water provision?
options: Private sector investment in water treatment
Government funding for community water projects
Private sector sponsorship of water supply initiatives
Public health agencies' involvement in water quality testing

title: What bottlenecks exist that could inform the response analysis and recommendations?
options: Insufficient local workforce for water projects
Community's willingness to adopt new practices
Availability of technical expertise for water solutions
Legal and regulatory hurdles for water projects
Political support for water provision initiatives

title: What opportunities exist that could inform the response analysis and recommendations?
options: Insufficient local workforce for water projects
Community's willingness to adopt new practices
Availability of technical expertise for water solutions
Legal and regulatory hurdles for water projects
Political support for water provision initiatives

options: Regular cleaning of water storage tanks
Routine inspection of water distribution systems
Educating the community about water conservation
Training local staff for system maintenance

title: Who shall be accountable for them?
What capacity is there to fulfill them in the short and long term?
options: Strong capacity with adequate resources and expertise
Limited capacity due to resource constraints
High capacity in the short term
but challenges in the long term
Capacity varies based on specific factors

title: Is there an existing or potential finance mechanism or system that can recover the operation and maintenance costs?
How does the host population access water and ensure that its water is safe at the point of use?
options: Using household water filters or purifiers
Treating water with chlorine or other disinfectants
No specific practices observed for water safety

title: Is there access to local markets?
What key WASH goods and services were accessible in the market before the crisis and are accessible during the crisis?
options: No significant WASH goods or services available

title: Who are the local partners in the geographical area, such as civil society groups that have similar capacity in WASH and community engagement?
Where do they buy water?
options: No specific water purchasing locations identified

title: Why are they buying water?
options: Lack of access to clean water sources

title: What is the ratio of average water price to average income?
What is the current defecation practice?
options: Open defecation in fields or open areas
Use of communal or shared latrines

title: Are there any existing facilities which operates successfully? If so, are they used? are they sufficient? Can they be extended or adapted?
Are the facilities safe and dignified: lighted, equipped with locks, privacy screens?
Are people familiar with the design, construction and use of toilets?
Can people access the toilet facilities during the day and night? If not at night, what are the alternatives?
Are the latrines or toilets cleaned and maintained so that they are hygienic and safe for all users?
Are people prepared to use latrines, defecation fields, trenches etc? (e.g. is it safe for women after dark, and are they safe/user friendly for children)
Are the users involved in the management and maintenance of latrines?
Are there any social – cultural norms to consider in the design of the toilet?
What are the cultural norms to consider in the design of the toilet?
options: Separate facilities for different age groups

title: Is there a designated area for public defecation?
Is there sufficient space for defecation fields, pit latrines etc?
Do current excreta disposal arrangements encourage vectors?
Do people have access to water and soap for washing hands after defecation?
Are there materials or water available for anal cleansing?

Are there any specific facilities or equipment available for making sanitation accessible for persons with disabilities, people living with HIV, people living with incontinence or people immobile in medical facilities?
What is the appropriate strategy for management of excreta?
What excreta management practices does the community practice?
How do women and girls manage menstruation? Are there appropriate materials or facilities available for this?
options: Access to clean water and soap for washing
Adequate restroom facilities with proper disposal options
Lack of appropriate materials and facilitie

title: From what age do children start to use the toilet?
What local materials are available for constructing toilets?
What are current beliefs and practices concerning excreta disposal?
options: Men and women use the same latrine
Different family members use separate latrines
Children's excreta is treated as hazardous
No specific beliefs or practices identified

title: Are soil conditions suitable for on-site excreta disposal?
What is the level of the groundwater table?

Have environmental considerations been assessed? (for example, the extraction of raw materials such as sand and gravel for construction purposes, and the protection of the environment from fecal matter)
Are there skilled workers in the community, such as masons or carpenters and unskilled laborers?
Are there available pit emptiers or desludging trucks? If so, is the collected fecal waste disposed of appropriately and safely?
Is there an existing acceptance of and practice for composting?
What is the slope of the terrain?
Are there any diseases/symptoms that are WASH-related?
Is there a high risk for vector-borne disease? How serious are they? (i.e. Any obvious problems with flies, mosquitoes, rodents, cockroaches, fleas, lice or bed bugs?)
If vector borne risks are high, do people have access to individual protection?
Is the affected population used to dealing with these risks? If so, how do they normally protect themselves?
Has the affected population traveled through an area infected with certain insect vectors?
Any evidence of overcrowding? ( Do people have previous experience of communal living?)
Do people have any livestock? If so, where do they live / defecate and what are the types?
Is there any evidence of vector breeding sites – stagnant water/ uncovered pit latrines/water containers etc.
What is known about the characteristics of the vector?
hintText: mosquito species, breeding, biting, resting habits

title: Is it possible to make changes to the local environment (by drainage/ scrub clearance/excreta disposal/refuse disposal) to discourage vector breeding?
Is it necessary to control vectors by chemical means? If so, What programmes, regulations and resources for vector control and use of chemicals are there?
Is there a National Public Health/Roll Back Malaria/Vector Control Programme?
Are people familiar with using ITN’s or bednets? In general, what are their sleeping practices?
options:
Sleeping indoors
Sleeping outdoors
Sleeping on mattresses or beds
Sleeping on the ground or floor
Using mosquito nets while sleeping
No specific sleeping practices identified

title: What daily or seasonal patterns do local vectors follow in relation to reproduction, resting and feeding?
options: Resting in indoor spaces during daylight
Feeding on humans during outdoor activities

title: Are there traditional beliefs and practices (for example, the belief that dirty water causes malarithat relate to vectors and vector-borne disease? Are any of these beliefs or practices either useful or harmful?
options: Belief that dirty water causes malaria
Hanging certain herbs to repel mosquitoes
Avoiding certain foods to prevent disease
Belief in local remedies for mosquito bites
Traditional practices for preventing mosquito breeding
No specific traditional beliefs or practices identified

title: What information and safety precautions need to be provided to households?
options: Proper use of insecticide-treated bed nets
Emptying and covering stagnant water sources
Avoiding outdoor activities during peak vector activity times
Seeking medical attention for suspected vector diseases
No specific information or precautions identified

title: In what quantity?

title: Are there medical facilities and activities producing waste? How is it disposed of? Who is responsible?

hintText: children’s nappies, menstruation hygiene materials and incontinence materials)?

title: Is their disposal discreet and effective?
What is the effect of the current solid waste disposal on the environment?

options: Public awareness campaigns on waste management
Collaboration with local communities for waste reduction

are there victims of trauma, injury, or shot wounds (see MHPSS section).

title: volunteer-based or hired
Is there a manager

title: Do vulnerable populations (children, women, people with disabilities, etc.) have access to shelters or safe spaces and other services?

options: Social support networks among community members
Accessing local religious or spiritual resources
No specific coping tools or strategies identified

title: Are you aware of any increased risks to vulnerable populations in the community as a result of the emergency? (e.g. CP risks, GBV)
How many people are affected by the emergency and where are they? Disaggregate the data by sex, age, disability and so on
General information regarding the entire local population - number of families, number of children/elderly/PWD?
What are people’s likely movements? What are the security factors for the affected people and for potential relief responses?
options: Migration to neighboring areas or countries
Seeking refuge in temporary shelters or camps
Returning to their homes after the situation stabilizes
Staying with relatives or host families
Unpredictable movements due to changing circumstances
Security concerns for affected people due to conflict or violence
Security concerns for relief efforts due to logistical challenges
Security concerns for relief efforts due to lack of access

title: What are your general impressions of the community?
options: Strong sense of community unity and cooperation
Limited access to basic services and amenities
High level of social engagement and activism

title: What are the main community social structures?
options: No specific main community social structures identified

title: What are the formal and informal power structures (for example, community leaders, elders, women’s groups)?
Who are the key people to consult or contact in the community?

options: Patriarchal structure with male head making most decisions
Matriarchal structure with female head making most decisions
Joint decision-making involving multiple family members
Decision-making based on age and seniority
Democratic process involving all family/community members
Influence of community leaders and elders
Decisions made by elected representatives or councils
Decisions based on traditional or cultural norms

title: What are the accepted beliefs and practices among the affected population?
options: Education and learning traditionsj) Communication and information-sharing methods

title: Are there cultural sensitivities or taboo subjects?
What are the accepted beliefs and practices or taboos among the affected population towards water, sanitation and hygiene?
options: Bathing at specific times of the day
Wearing specific clothing for hygiene purposes
No specific beliefs or practices identified

title: Do people have access to cash and/or credit?
Are there seasonal variations to be aware of that may restrict access or increase demands on labor? (for example, during harvesting time)

Which segments of the population can and should be targeted (for example, mothers, children, community leaders, religious leaders)?
